Rosie_Flores:
{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2019}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Rosie Flores | image = Rosie Flores (8287136181) (cropped).jpg | caption = Rosie Flores at the [[Peabody Award|67th Annual Peabody Awards]] in 2008 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Rosalie Flores{{cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/320436462 |title=BANDERA HIGHWAY |website=ASCAP |publisher=American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers |access-date=March 13, 2023}} | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1950|9|10}} | origin = [[San Antonio|San Antonio, Texas]], U.S. | instrument = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}} | genre = {{hlist|[[Alternative country]]|[[country rock]]|[[cowpunk]]|[[rockabilly]]}} | occupation = {{hlist|Singer|guitarist|songwriter}} | years_active = 1968–present | label = {{hlist|[[Reprise Records|Reprise]]|[[HighTone Records|HighTone]]|[[Rounder Records|Rounder]]|[[Watermelon Records|Watermelon]]|Eminent|Durango Rose|Emergent|Bloodshot Records}} | associated_acts = Rosie and the Screamers
[[Screamin' Sirens]]
[[Asleep at the Wheel]] | website = {{URL|rosieflores.com/}} }} '''Rosie Flores''' (born '''Rosalie Flores'''; September 10, 1950) is an American singer, songwriter and musician. She currently resides in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], Texas, where August 31 was declared Rosie Flores Day by the Austin City Council in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.austintexas.gov/search404|title=Search Results – AustinTexas.gov – The Official Website of the City of Austin|website=Austintexas.gov|access-date=February 28, 2019}} ==Biography== Rosie Flores was born in [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]], United States, where she lived until the age of twelve, when her family moved to [[San Diego]]. In interviews, Flores has recalled that growing up, she loved to watch musical television shows like ''[[The Dick Clark Show]]'' and ''[[Hit Parade]]''. She began singing as a young child, and her brother, Roger, taught her to play rhythm guitar when she was a teenager.{{cite book|last1=Hudson|first1=Kathleen|title=Women in Texas Music: Stories and Songs|date=2013|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0292752863|pages=69–73}} Flores formed her first band, Penelope's Children, while still in high school in California.{{cite web|last1=Davis|first1=John T.|title=Rosie Flores Still Rockin'|url=http://www.austinwomanmagazine.com/articles/rosie-flores-still-rockin|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402161755/http://www.austinwomanmagazine.com/articles/rosie-flores-still-rockin|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 2, 2015|website=Austin Woman Magazine|access-date=March 7, 2015}} In the 1970s, Flores played the San Diego nightclub circuit and was the namesake of the [[alt country]]/[[cowpunk]] band Rosie and the Screamers. After leaving the Screamers, she joined a cowpunk [[all-female band]] called [[Screamin' Sirens]] in the 1980s.Gary Indiana, "Screamin' Sirens," Flipside, whole no. 49 (Summer 1986), pp. 18–19. The latter band produced a series of 7-inch singles and tracks for compilation albums before releasing an album in 1987, ''Voodoo.'' Flores's self-titled solo debut came out on [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]]/[[Reprise Records|Reprise]] in 1987. The single, "Crying Over You", put her on the ''Billboard'' chart for the first time.{{cite news|last1=Arnold|first1=Thomas K|title=TWO SINGERS HOPE ALL IS 'ROSIE' ON THE COMEBACK TRAIL : Flores Comes Full Circle, Returns to Traditional Country|url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1987-09-16-ca-5220-story.html|access-date=March 7, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=September 16, 1987}} Since then, Flores has recorded ten additional solo albums. Flores has toured widely, appearing in the United States, Europe, Asia, and Australia, and also performing frequently in Austin, continuing into 2019.{{cite web |publisher=Rosie Flores |title=Rosie Flores: Tour |url=https://rosieflores.com/wp/tour/ |year=2019 |access-date=January 6, 2019}} In 1995, she joined [[Wanda Jackson]] on a coast-to-coast North American tour,{{Cite web|url=http://www.rosieflores.com/influenc.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070909221520/http://www.rosieflores.com/influenc.html|url-status=dead|title=Rosie Flores Official Web Site|archive-date=September 9, 2007|access-date=August 6, 2021}} and she toured as a member of [[Asleep at the Wheel]] in 1997.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2213&dat=19970412&id=JagkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bjoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2228,1441285|title=Calhoun Times and Gordon County News – Google News Archive Search|access-date=February 28, 2019}} She has also traveled with a concert tribute she created to honor [[Janis Martin]], a program which she performed at the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum]] among other places.{{cite web|title=Rosie Flores: A Tribute to Janis Martin|url=http://rockhall.com/event/rosie-flores--a-tribute-to-janis-martin/|website=Rockhall.org|access-date=March 7, 2015}} In 2012, she was part of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's tribute to Chuck Berry.{{cite news|last1=Yarborough|first1=Chuck|title=Rock Hall's Chuck Berry American Music Masters tribute: Range of performers paying homage to '50s pioneer|url=http://www.cleveland.com/music/index.ssf/2012/10/rock_and_roll_hall_of_fames_ch.html|access-date=March 7, 2015|work=Cleveland Plain Dealer|date=October 26, 2012}} Her media appearances include ''[[Austin City Limits]]'' and ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', and she had a cameo role in the 1993 film ''[[The Thing Called Love]]''. In addition to her work as a performer and songwriter, Flores has helped to revive the careers of female rockabilly musicians from previous generations and to create new interest in their music. Her album ''Rockabilly Filly'', released on Hightone Records in 1995, included vocals from early rock and roll musicians [[Janis Martin]] and [[Wanda Jackson]].{{cite web|title=Rockabilly Filly Overview|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/rockabilly-filly-mw0000177263|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=March 7, 2015}} In 2007, Flores brought Janis Martin to a recording studio in Blanco, Texas, to record what would be both Martin's first solo album in thirty years as well as her last before her death of cancer.{{cite web|title=Janis Martin, 'The Female Elvis,' Returns|url=https://www.npr.org/2012/09/30/161968431/janis-martin-the-female-elvis-returns|publisher=NPR|access-date=March 7, 2015}} After the project was turned down by a number of record labels, Flores raised more than $16,000 on Kickstarter to release the album, which was titled ''Janis Martin: The Blanco Sessions''. Flores is credited as a producer.{{cite web|last1=Flores|first1=Rosie|title=JANIS MARTIN " The Female Elvis", Final Recording Sessions|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1383637978/janis-martin-the-female-elvis-final-recording-sess|website=Kickstarter.com|access-date=March 7, 2015}} Flores's current (as of 2013–2018) guitar of choice is her James Trussart SteeltopCaster. She uses [[Fender amplifier]]s, and has also played [[Fender Telecaster]]s, [[Gretsch]] electrics, [[Gibson Les Paul]]s, and various acoustic guitars.{{cite web |date=January 9, 2013 |author=Charupakorn, Joe |title=Interview: Rosie Flores – Rockabilly Road Doggie |publisher=[[Premier Guitar]] |url=https://www.premierguitar.com/articles/Interview_Rosie_Flores_Rockabilly_Road_Doggie |access-date=January 6, 2019}} == Musical style== {{Expand section|date=January 2023}} According to ''[[AllMusic]]'', Flores's "talent for [[alternative country]] and [[rockabilly]] made her a favorite with both audiences and critics."{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/rosie-flores-mn0000851550/biography |title=Rosie Flores Biography |last=Manheim |first=James |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=2022-01-05}} ''Nashville Scene'' defined Flores as a "[[New wave music|New Wave]] [[country rock|country-rock]]er".{{cite web |url=https://www.nashvillescene.com/music/chris-hillman-rosie-flores-and-many-more-celebrate-the-story-of-country-rock/article_59eb7b22-4340-11ed-9bb2-4b3e1e763e22.html |title=Chris Hillman, Rosie Flores and Many More Celebrate the Story of Country-Rock |last=Hurt |first=Edd |date=October 3, 2022 |publisher=Nashville Scene |access-date=2022-01-05}} ''San Diego Tribune'' described Flores as a "dynamo of rockabilly and [[cowpunk|cow-punk]]" who is "equally gifted as a singer, songwriter, guitarist and band leader [and] shines whether performing country, rock, swing or any of the other earthy American styles she has made her own."{{cite web |url=https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/entertainment/music/sd-et-artscal-rosie-flores-20170626-story.html |title=Rosie Flores, San Diego-bred dynamo of rockabilly and cow-punk, returns |last=Varga |first=George |date=July 2, 2017 |publisher=San Diego Tribune |access-date=2022-01-05}} ==Personal life== Flores has revealed that, under pressure from her manager, she had an abortion in 1986, shortly after signing with Warner Bros. She later regretted the decision. She has never been married, and has said that her lifestyle, which involves frequent touring, makes it difficult to maintain long-term relationships. ==Discography== {{Main|Rosie Flores discography}} ==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Association !! Category !! Nominated Work !!
